NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan takes upper floor at 10 Portman Square
Ardagh Glass signs at 10 Portman Square

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
10 Portman Square is a 132,000 sq ft office building with retail units at ground and lower ground level.

The building was designed by Jestico and Wiles and is a seven storey building, benefitting from natural light on four sides with typical floors of 18,500 sq ft.

10 Portman Square has already been let to the investment manager, Aspect Capital, who occupy 24,500 sq ft on the top two floors, and Aramco Overseas Company UK Ltd, who occupy 24,400 sq ft over the fifth and part fourth floors.

Property.PROP_DESCRIPTION: A residential development opportunity in the City

BLOG.title: Exceeding Carbon Reduction Targets at Aldgate Place
BLOG.description: Embodied carbon comprises emissions from extracting, manufacturing, transporting and assembling construction materials – one of the largest aspects of British Land’s carbon footprint. Aldgate Place is our mixed use development near the City with Barratt London. It will create new residential units including affordable homes, as well as a new hotel, office accommodation, retail space, restaurants, cafés and public spaces. To deliver an efficient structural solution, the design uses post-tensioned concrete, with high-strength steel strands providing reinforcement. Our structural engineering partner, Walsh Group, has a strong track record on post-tensioned concrete, winning several industry awards. Through detailed analysis at design stage, informed by...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT: Aldgate Place is a joint venture between British Land and Barratt London, creating a vibrant new community in the heart of Aldgate. The regeneration of the 2 acre site will provide a range of different uses including approximately 463 residential units, 19,000 sq ft of commercial space, 14,000 sq ft of retail space and a new Hotel. Phase 1 includes 304 apartments, of which 150 will be affordable, and the new hotel, and is expected to complete in 2017.

Out of town retail park

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Mayflower is a 25 year old shopping park, extensively refurbished and remodelled in 2014

Located just a few miles north of Basildon town centre, Mayflower shopping park covers over 150,000 sq ft of retail accommodation, with key occupiers including Homebase, Sports Direct, Outfit, Next, M&S Simply Food, Boots, Costa Coffee and Pizza Hut.

It was extensively refurbished in 2014, with significant improvements to the public realm, walkways, car parks, signage, landscaping and seating. The changes met with a very positive response, increasing dwell time, conversion rates and customer ratings and successfully attracting more affluent shoppers.

A prime 460,000 sq ft open air retail scheme next to Bath Spa railway station
Property.PROP_WEBSITE_SUBTEXT: Offering some of the best configured retail space in Bath, it also offers the largest car park in the city, as well as the top eight retailers, leisure units and office accommodation.

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: Restaurants hungry for space at SouthGate, Bath
Fat Face to Double Up in SouthGate, Bath

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Prime open air retail scheme, in the centre of the historic spa town of Bath

SouthGate Bath is owned in joint venture with Aviva Investors, following British Land’s acquisition of a 50% share in 2013. The 430,000 sq ft scheme is adjacent to the Bath Spa railway station, and forms the south east quadrant of Bath city centre. The scheme, which first opened in 2009 is designed to be in keeping with the historic town. It comprises 55 retail units, 14 leisure units, a car park and 25,000 sq ft of office accommodation.

The scheme, anchored by Debenhams, H&M, Topshop and Boots has attracted a number of high street fashion brands including Hollister, Urban Outfitters, All Saints and Boux Avenue, as well as Apple. The catering offering includes Pizza Express, Giraffe, Gourmet Burger Kitchen, Nando’s and Prezzo, as well as a street food market every fortnight.

Bath is a historic city with UNESCO world heritage status, and one of the top tourist destinations in the UK, attracting around 4.6m tourists per year.

Property.PROP_DESCRIPTION: A listed building in Covent Garden providing high quality residential accommodation

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Listed luxury development in Covent Garden

17-19 Bedford Street is a luxury residential development of 17 apartments, in a Grade 2 Listed Building in the heart of Covent Garden. Apartments within this development retain classic high ceilings and spacious floor plans which compliment Covent Garden’s historic elegance and artistic originality. Fine materials such as Carrara marble, porcelain and double-fumed oak are featured throughout. This recently completed development, which was listed in the top 10 niche and boutique schemes for the CBRE Hot 100 properties in 2014, is now sold out.

BLOG.title: Broadgate Connect – Changing Lives
BLOG.description: Many of the people I’ve engaged with through Broadgate Connect would never otherwise have thought of trying to secure a job in the City. From long-term jobseekers to young people looking for their first job, it is so fulfilling to have a positive impact on an individual’s progression and success. I am grateful to Broadgate employers for the opportunities that they have created, opening doors for local people and giving them access to roles that many would never have imagined for themselves. In turn, it is great to see the employers benefiting from motivated, committed employees with new skills and ideas. Since...

BLOG.title: Broadgate Connect Benefits East London
BLOG.description:
Since we launched our innovative employment and skills initiative with community partner the East London Business Alliance (ELBA) in 2012, our project managers have engaged with 429 East London residents, helping connect them to job opportunities and work placements in the City. We are delighted at the success of the project, which is benefiting both local jobseekers and our Broadgate suppliers. Two thirds of the engaged candidates come from our target boroughs of Hackney and Tower Hamlets. More than 70% are from black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) groups. Benefits for local residents include:
Early access to job opportunities, with...

BLOG.title: Spring into Wellbeing at Broadgate
BLOG.description:
Research shows that a healthier workforce is generally more productive and happier, delivering benefits for both employees and employers. Over 35 teams kick-started their new year by battling it out on the ice with friends and colleagues in our popular Broomball tournaments. Others learnt how to skate with grace and style, thanks to lessons from our skate coach, Robert Burgerman, recently a coach on ITV’s Dancing on Ice.
Broomball players batting the ball with their ‘broom’ and young skaters building confidence and skills on the ice. Each year, we give local schoolchildren the chance to enjoy sessions for free. Summer Live will begin...

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: British Land and GIC submit planning application for 100 Liverpool Street

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
100 Liverpool Street sits at the entrance to the forthcoming Crossrail station at Liverpool Street station

We have received planning permission for a refurbishment of 100 Liverpool Street covering 515,000 sq ft of office and retail space. The revised plans will add three further floors to the building over 135,000 sq ft, and will improve local connections and public spaces between 100 Liverpool Street, Liverpool Street Station and Broadgate Circle. The introduction of retail space will animate the ground floor, and improve the catering and retail selection for occupiers. Designed by Hopkins Architects, the proposal will retain the structural frame of the building, but use gently curving facades to give it a fresh identity.

Property.PROP_DESCRIPTION: Revitalised Broadgate Circle with London's latest dining hub

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: Main Units at £20m Broadgate Circle Scheme Fully Pre-let

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Broadgate Circle has been comprehensively redeveloped to create a dedicated, high end dining hub for this part of the City.

Broadgate Circle lies at the heart of the campus. The £20m redevelopment completed in 2015, adding a diverse mix of brands focused around the new public space. These include Yauatcha from the Michelin starred Hakkasan Group, French café concept Aubaine, Lebanese café Comptoir Libanais and The Botanist bar and restaurant. With a mix of street food traders, and pioneering gym concept 1Rebel, this new development provides an exciting new destination for the City.

This redevelopment forms part of our broader vision for the campus, to create a vibrant, mixed use environment serving the growing areas to the north and east, such as Shoreditch, Spitalfields and TechCity as well as Broadgate itself which is expected to benefit from the opening of Crossrail in 2018.

Sustainability

The redevelopment of Broadgate Circle incorporated several key environmental features, which included:

  • Reduced embodied carbon and environmental impact from the use of materials, achieved through retaining greater than 80% of the existing building structure, and the design and selection of materials according to lifecycle impact and responsible sourcing objectives.
  • Integration of high environmental design and construction standards with achievement of certification to a BREEAM ‘Very Good’ rating including high scores attained in Land Use and Ecology, Management, Transport and Pollution categories.
  • Conservation and enhancement of site biodiversity by retaining an existing vegetated trellis and living walls, and planting of additional varieties of ecologically valuable climbing plants, such as honeysuckle. These ecological features also connect to and form part of the Broadgate Estate’s network of green infrastructure, including green roof and soft landscaped areas.
  • Installation of a water efficient irrigation system for trellis and living walls, which features rainwater harvesting and an automatic watering system designed to adapt to the changing climatic conditions.

BLOG.title: Green Roofs Go Mainstream
BLOG.description: Green roofs not only encourage urban biodiversity, they can cut carbon emissions from energy use by improving building insulation, reduce local flood risks by slowing rainwater run-off rates, enhance air quality and often create pleasant spaces that add to people’s sense of wellbeing. When we first included green roofs in our Sustainability Brief in 2004, we needed to work closely with our design partners and property teams to design, plant and maintain habitats that really enhanced biodiversity. Since then, we’ve created green roofs on 12 new buildings in central London, with more under design, and have successfully retrofitted them to some...

BLOG.title: Out with the Old and in with the New – Energy Efficient Lighting at Broadgate
BLOG.description:
We chose LED products because they offered energy savings, improved quality of light, longer rated lifetimes and a major reduction in maintenance costs compared with previous fittings. Here’s some of what we’ve replaced and installed across the Estate over the last two years:
80 fittings along the Great Eastern Walkway, from 150W to 36W LEDs – 76% more efficient 72 fittings in the EBRD staircase lobby towards Exchange Square, from 36W to 14W LEDs – 61% more efficient Fittings across the Bishopsgate service roadway from 150W to 14W LEDs – 91% more efficient Lamps in the Bishopsgate...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Situated around Exchange Square, Exchange House is one of the most recognisable buildings on the campus

Designed by architects Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, Exchange House was completed in 1990 and covers around 390,000 sq ft. Like much of Broadgate, it is constructed above the tracks of Liverpool Street station on a construction raft. The building is erected on arches that use bridge-building technology to distribute weight onto giant foundation piers, and two steel arches, seemingly decorative, span two sides of the building, supporting its weight. The construction also provides for large areas of public space around the building.

In 2015, the building was awarded the American Institute of Architects 25-year Award, in recognition of an unusual and effective structural system, combining design and function.

Herbert Smith occupies over half of the space, with F&C Asset Management, and Société Générale being other key occupiers.

In turn, it is great to see the employers benefiting from motivated, committed employees with new skills and ideas. Since...

BLOG.title: Broadgate Connect Benefits East London
BLOG.description:
Since we launched our innovative employment and skills initiative with community partner the East London Business Alliance (ELBA) in 2012, our project managers have engaged with 429 East London residents, helping connect them to job opportunities and work placements in the City. We are delighted at the success of the project, which is benefiting both local jobseekers and our Broadgate suppliers. Two thirds of the engaged candidates come from our target boroughs of Hackney and Tower Hamlets. More than 70% are from black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) groups. CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
199 Bishopsgate is a 146,000 sq ft (13,600 sq m) Grade A office building with typical floors 14,460 sq ft.

Located on a principal City thoroughfare, 199 Bishopsgate draws great advantage from being part of Broadgate – one of the world's most prestigious financial, corporate and legal office locations.

Designed by John Robertson Architects, the building launched September 2012.

Flexible, largely uninterrupted floors enjoy great views of the City and natural light. The building is 50% let.

BLOG.title: The Joy of Working in a Building that we Designed
BLOG.description:
We are delighted to be working in a building that exemplifies SOM’s design ethos, encompassing master planning, architecture, structural engineering and interior design. Moreover, the project signals our firm’s growing presence in London. Having won numerous awards for the design of the tower, including Best Tall Building in Europe, we recently scooped first place for our interior works at The Broadgate Tower from the American Society of Interior Designers (Illinois). Making the architecture work to our advantage
An air-rights building, situated above 18 train tracks leading into Liverpool Street station,...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
At 540 ft, the Broadgate Tower is the only high-rise building in the Broadgate campus and a key addition to the estate.

Designed by architects Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the construction of the Broadgate Tower, completed in August 2008 marked a major phase in the construction of the Broadgate campus. The 35-storey building is one of the tallest buildings in the City. It is situated just north of Liverpool Street station, based on a construction raft above the entrance and covers nearly 400,000 sq ft. It is multi-let to a number of tenants including the building’s architects, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, Reed Smith, Hill Dickinson, Banco Itau, Itochu Europe, William Blair and Liquidnet.

It also provided the backdrop to a scene in Shanghai, in the James Bond film Skyfall.

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: FSC® puts spotlight on 5 Broadgate

BLOG.title: Sustainability Excellence at 5 Broadgate
BLOG.description:
Architectural firm Make started with a solid object and cut into it, to allow light in and views out where needed – minimising the energy needed for cooling, heating and lighting, at the same time as promoting the wellbeing of those in the building. Photovoltaic panels on the roof also harness the sun’s power to generate clean energy.
Like all our new office buildings, 5 Broadgate is rated BREEAM Excellent for sustainability. It achieved a BREEAM score in the top 10 of all London office developments to date and really showcases our sustainability strategy in action.
Future proofing Designed to be over 50%...

BLOG.title: Green Roofs Go Mainstream
BLOG.description: Green roofs not only encourage urban biodiversity, they can cut carbon emissions from energy use by improving building insulation, reduce local flood risks by slowing rainwater run-off rates, enhance air quality and often create pleasant spaces that add to people’s sense of wellbeing. When we first included green roofs in our Sustainability Brief in 2004, we needed to work closely with our design partners and property teams to design, plant and maintain habitats that really enhanced biodiversity. Since then, we’ve created green roofs on 12 new buildings in central London, with more under design, and have successfully retrofitted them to some...

BLOG.title: It’s Official – 5 Broadgate Team is Exceptional
BLOG.description: It was great to read the Considerate Constructors Scheme’s report, which describes 5 Broadgate as “a fine example of a very well-considered and managed project that has produced an exceptional performance”. The report also highlights the team’s “professional and detailed approach” and their “ambition to progress and demonstrate real improvement at every visit”. I was particularly pleased to see the feedback on the 5 Broadgate community programme, which the report states has “benefited many people in a variety of ways in the immediate vicinity of the project and also provided much needed employment opportunity”. A big thank you to Mace, the...

BLOG.title: Integrated approach to waste at 5 Broadgate brings benefits
BLOG.description:
Monitoring and benchmarking
When it comes to sustainability, our ability to monitor our performance is at the heart of our success. 5 Broadgate was Mace’s first major project to use our online portal, Optimise, to capacity. This allows us to track waste management and other key performance indicators in real time, including responsible sourcing of materials, carbon emissions, water use, timber, Considerate Constructors Scheme scores and biodiversity. By managing environmental and social reporting in one single portal, we are mirroring lessons learnt from the development of health and safety management tools such as our Yellow Jacket, where a simple dashboard gives...

BLOG.title: Life as a Bricklaying Apprentice at 5 Broadgate
BLOG.description: Through research I discovered that Hackney Community College was offering a course, in line with my previous experience, that would give me a Level 2 Diploma in Brickwork. I was accepted on the course and, due to my determination of wanting to pursue my dream of becoming a bricklayer, I successfully finished the course within six months. To my surprise, I was then offered a fantastic opportunity to be enrolled onto an NVQ Level 2 apprenticeship in brickwork with Swift Brickwork Contractors. This opportunity has surely enabled me build my confidence within this area of work. Having to adapt to the cultural...

BLOG.title: Life as a Mechanical and Electrical Apprentice at 5 Broadgate
BLOG.description: I made the decision not to go to college full time but to look for an apprenticeship. I have been given an amazing opportunity to work on one of the largest single office buildings in London’s financial district, known as 5 Broadgate. I work with the Mace team that delivers mechanical and electrical services. I have had the chance to work alongside project managers, lead engineers and cost managers. I have worked closely on a few mechanical and electrical packages, such as smoke extraction systems and distribution boards. I regularly take part in weekly review meetings. It didn’t take long till...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
5 Broadgate, our new world class office building for UBS, completed in June 2015.

Designed by Make Architects, the building covers 710,000 sq ft over twelve storeys, housing up to 6,000 people and featuring four large trading floors, each able to accommodate around 750 traders. It is currently the largest “groundscraper” in London, and also one of the world’s greenest buildings, with 65% lower carbon emissions than the previous two buildings on this site. Architecturally, it marks a move away from the more traditional glass facades across the campus.

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: British Land Sells £210 million of Apartments at New Super-Prime London Residential Development, Clarges Mayfair

BLOG.title: Sustainability – Helping to Create Places People Prefer
BLOG.description: I am excited about our new sustainability strategy, which completely aligns with our commercial focus on Places People Prefer. Our new targets to 2020 have come from engagement with people across our business, as well as with key stakeholders and external experts. Our approach means that everything is pointing in the same direction, with our social and environmental ambitions core to what we want to do as a business. Our new strategy will help us to further build positive, personal experiences with our stakeholders. Our community programme will further extend local people’s personal connections with our places. Our greater emphasis on...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Super Prime residential development in the heart of Mayfair

Clarges Mayfair is a luxury residential-led development in Mayfair, close to Bond Street and overlooking Green Park and Buckingham Palace. On completion, there will be 34 apartments arranged over ten floors, ranging in size from one-bedroom to five-bedroom residences. The development will include a private wellness spa with a 25m swimming pool and fully equipped gymnasium, sauna, steam and treatment rooms as well as a private cinema. Residents will benefit from gated mews, with secure drop off points, and full lifestyle services.

The site was acquired by British Land in 2012 for £129.6 million with revised planning consent achieved the following year to increase the high-end residential element of the scheme from 63,000 sq ft to 93,500 sq ft. The revised scheme includes 47,800 sq ft of high quality prime office space and 14,800 of retail and leisure space.

Construction began on site in 2014, with the residential element due to complete in 2017. Over half (by number) of the apartments have been pre-sold, following the release of a selected number of apartments for marketing in summer 2014. Marketing of the remaining units will be undertaken closer to completion.

Sustainability at Clarges

  • 41/50 Considerate Constructors Scheme score, reflecting care for community, environment, safety and more.
  • 100% sustainable timber used in construction and 99% of construction waste recycled.
  • 82 students on site tours, 30 work placements and 38 activities in local schools and colleges.
  • 53 tr

Former factory workers, their families and local children...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Marble Arch House lies at the corner of Seymour Street and Edgware Road, within the Portman Village

Designed by Bennett’s Associates Architects, Marble Arch House provides 61,200 sq ft of modern office space and 15,000 sq ft of retail space. It is conveniently located for Marble Arch underground station, with Marylebone and Paddington mainline stations also nearby. Oxford Street and Hyde Park are just a short walk away.

The building completed in 2014 has let well. Occupiers include Fulcrum Asset Management, Access Industries, NERA Economic Consulting, private investor BXR Partners and global gaming company GTECH. The retail space on the ground floor has been let to operators including Paul’s Bakery, As Nature Intended and Paperchase. Adjacent to the new office building is a 10,000 sq ft development of ten luxury residential apartments built behind the retained period Victorian facade of 62-64 Seymour Street, all of which have been sold.

The development has been designed to achieve a BREEAM 'Excellent' environmental rating.

Marble Arch House is also situated adjacent to our York House building.

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: Broadgate Estates takes space at 2 Kingdom Street, Paddington Central

BLOG.title: BREEAM Outstanding for Broadgate Estates at The Hub
BLOG.description: Our new facility at 2 Kingdom Street, Paddington Central, is all about making sure that we’ve got the right talent delivering great service for our clients. We’re delighted to have achieved the world’s first BREEAM Outstanding Fit Out – the highest possible rating, scoring 85.6%. Our in-house sustainability experts worked closely on design and delivery with architects Magnus + Associates, project managers GVA Acuity, contractor Overbury and services engineers Edward Pearce. We set a robust and exacting brief, reflecting our experience advising clients on fit outs. The whole team knew exactly what was expected from the start, and they really took...

BLOG.title: Public Realm and Wellbeing at Paddington Central
BLOG.description:
Paddington Central enjoys easy access to Regent’s Canal, a unique feature. Through our first phase of improvements, we enhanced the canalside area and other public spaces, embedding our wellbeing principles throughout. We widened walkways, improved cycle routes and added extra bike spaces to enhance the visitor experience and make it easier for people working and living at Paddington to enjoy an active commute, which studies show can make us happier and healthier.
We also added different types of landscaping, creating green walls, planting mature trees and filling large planters with herbs. Good news for people and nature, with growing evidence that green...

BLOG.title: Taking the Paddington Trail
BLOG.description: The statue adopted by Paddington Central is one of 50 Paddington Bears forming a trail across London, organised by VisitLondon.com and Studio Canal. The route tracks Paddington’s favourite locations, taking in museums, parks, shops and landmarks. Each statue will be auctioned in December to raise funds for the NSPCC, a charity whose work is all about protecting vulnerable children. Together with our Paddington Central team, we wanted our bear to be a beacon of excellence within our community and so we invited students from nearby Westminster Academy to present their designs for his appearance. The students created a range of mixed-media...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
2 Kingdom is the largest property on the campus, multi-let to a strong line up of high calibre tenants

2 Kingdom Street is the most significant property on the campus, providing 268,000 sq ft of high quality, multi-let office space over 12 floors. Designed by Sheppard Robson, the building was completed in 2010 and has typical floor plates of 26,000 sq ft, which can be easily divided to allow up to three separate tenancies per floor. Key tenants include Microsoft, Statoil, Vertex Pharmaceuticals and Regus.

We widened walkways, improved cycle routes and added extra bike spaces to enhance the visitor experience and make it easier for people working and living at Paddington to enjoy an active commute, which studies show can make us happier and healthier.
We also added different types of landscaping, creating green walls, planting mature trees and filling large planters with herbs. Good news for people and nature, with growing evidence that green...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
We are on site at 4 Kingdom Street, creating flexible office space, with a high standard of amenities for occupiers

We are currently on site at 4 Kingdom Street, for a 147,000 sq ft office building.  Architects Allies and Morrison reviewed and updated the original plan, improving the flexibility of the office floorplates and adding new amenities for occupiers.  The redesigned building will have typical floor plates of 15,000 sq ft each with a large corner terrace and a glass pod designed as a creative meeting space. The building includes a new communal roof terrace which provides outside space for break-out, entertaining and sporting facilities.  Practical completion is expected in 2017.

3 Sheldon Square is the second multi-let office property, comprising 143,000 sq ft of office space over 11 floors. Part of the first phase of development at Paddington Central, it was completed in September 2002 and offers typical office floor plates extending to 13,000 sq ft, providing highly flexible, efficient open-plan accommodation. Tenants include Kingfisher plc, Prudential plc and Cerner Corporation.

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Retail and leisure cluster at the centre of the campus

The Sheldon Square retail area, a grass amphitheatre surrounded by cafés, bars and restaurants, is adjacent to 3 Sheldon Square and consists of 16 retail units, with retailers including ITSU, Pret, Tossed, Sainsbury's and Starbucks, together with a Nuffield Health Centre. Six of the retail units and the Nuffield Health Centre are located at terrace level bordering the central amphitheatre at the heart of Paddington Central. A further 10 units are located canal side producing an attractive mix of retail, restaurant and leisure. British Land also own the freehold in respect of 200 residential units sold to St. George on long leases which sit above the retail area.

BLOG.title: Arts and Enlivenment at Regent’s Place
BLOG.description: More and more we’re looking at what else we can do to enliven our places. At Regent’s Place, the New Diorama Theatre and Diorama Arts Studios add something unique, attracting a diverse mix of people onto the campus, creating a point of difference and contributing to a community feel that you simply couldn’t get from a standalone office scheme. Our Regent’s Place team also includes people whose main focus is on engaging with occupiers and local community groups and enlivening the campus. And we’re exploring new opportunities to make the public realm an even more enjoyable place to spend time, adding...

BLOG.title: Community Partnerships at Regent’s Place
BLOG.description: The efforts and achievements of the Regent’s Place team were recognised by Camden Council in the Camden 50 Exceptional Volunteering Awards 2015. But what’s really striking is how many different people and businesses at Regent’s Place are now involved in community projects – and how much benefit this brings to the local area. Whether it’s the Regent’s Place team volunteering, occupiers on the campus contributing funds and in-kind support, suppliers supporting employment and training initiatives, or office workers donating to food bank collections, it really is a team effort. An incredible 7,080 people benefited from the Regent’s Place community programme last...

BLOG.title: Green Roofs Go Mainstream
BLOG.description: Green roofs not only encourage urban biodiversity, they can cut carbon emissions from energy use by improving building insulation, reduce local flood risks by slowing rainwater run-off rates, enhance air quality and often create pleasant spaces that add to people’s sense of wellbeing. When we first included green roofs in our Sustainability Brief in 2004, we needed to work closely with our design partners and property teams to design, plant and maintain habitats that really enhanced biodiversity. Since then, we’ve created green roofs on 12 new buildings in central London, with more under design, and have successfully retrofitted them to some...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
The redevelopment of 10-30 Brock Street completed in 2013.

The largest development, 10 Brock Street, was designed by Wilkinson Eyre and provides 340,000 sq ft of office accommodation. It incorporates three glass sections of 8, 10 and 16 storeys, with floor to ceiling glazed external cladding. All floors have now been let to a diverse range of occupiers including Debenhams, Santander AM, Manchester City FC and Facebook.

30 Brock Street provides 20,000 sq ft of offices designed by Marshall Architects and Tate Hindle, with 3,500 sq ft floorplates arranged over the 1st to 6th floors. Occupiers include The Guinness Partnership, a charitable housing trust, Sainsbury’s and Itsu.

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
The Triton Building, NW1

The Triton Building at Regent’s Place is a 26-storey residential tower which was completed in 2013. The tower has a distinctive basket weave façade and the design affords stunning views across Regent’s Park. The development is located within Regents Place, a 13 acre; fully managed campus owned by British Land, featuring unrivalled local and international transport links, a mix of retail, leisure and public spaces – all within close proximity to Regents Park. The apartments are built to a high level of specification with underfloor heating and comfort cooling throughout and most apartments have a private balcony. The Triton Building apartments are now sold out and British Land retains the freehold.

BLOG.title: Air Source Energy at Regent’s Place
BLOG.description: When the traditional chiller and boiler system at 350 Euston Road was due for replacement, British Land and our property management partner at Regent’s Place, Broadgate Estates Ltd, joined forces with Climaveneta to identify the most efficient solution. Together, we developed a comprehensive energy model to simulate how the building operates, so we could test different options. The old central heating, ventilation and cooling (HVAC) system comprised three boilers, two air-cooled chillers and two air handling units (AHUs) without heat recovery, as well as fan coils on the floors. We looked at two main solutions. Firstly, replacing the existing units with...

BLOG.title: Whiteley Shopping scales new heights
BLOG.description: Indoor leisure concept ‘Rock Up’ caters for the whole family by combining 26 different climbs, a soft play area for toddlers and high quality food. We helped fund this start up business as an innovative offer for customers. It’s an approach we’ve taken before to help new businesses which we believe can really help us create Places People Prefer and a real point of difference for our schemes. In the case of Whiteley we thought it would be interesting to see if the concept increased awareness of the scheme and could extend the catchment. We agreed a profit share and while...

BLOG.title: Dementia Friendly Places
BLOG.description: We want our shopping destinations to be open to everyone to enjoy. Wide, safe walkways, convenient parking, accessible toilets and clear signage – this all helps. But, as a placemaker, we know that it’s our people on the ground who can make the biggest difference. So, alongside WorldHost customer service training, we’re making sure that our centre teams have the understanding and skills to help visitors who might need additional support. There are around 850,000 people with dementia in the UK, often cared for by family members. It can make an enormous difference to their day to encounter people who know...

BLOG.title: How can Property Change Communities for the Better?
BLOG.description: So, at British Land, we focus on creating Places People Prefer. If we provide places that directly address those things that are important to people – where they can interact with their friends, families and colleagues, pleasant, resource efficient environments, with plenty of natural daylight, attractive walkways to get to work, showers and facilities to enable active lifestyles, green spaces and lots of amenities – we can make a positive impact on people’s everyday lives, at the same time as growing our business. If we contribute positively to local economies through local procurement and employment, as well as through our basic...

BLOG.title: Creating Space for Local Communities – The Treehouse
BLOG.description: This unique, pop-up space hosted a four-month programme of events designed to support the local community and enhance shoppers’ experience. We ran a popular Bid4Space competition, which offered local individuals, groups and businesses the chance to win a week in The Treehouse free of charge to showcase their ideas and offers, and test new concepts. Altogether, over 50 independent retailers, charities, artists and local entrepreneurs held events in The Treehouse. In fact, the facility proved so successful we are now exploring opportunities to move it to other properties – made possible by the fact that The Treehouse was constructed from five...

The map below shows the number of new retail jobs that could be created around the UK through our committed and prospective retail development pipeline.
The launch of Whiteley Shopping in Hampshire created over 1,000 jobs in 50 shops, cafés and restaurants. Demand for the roles was so high that almost 4,000 people attended the recruitment day, queuing from 8am for the chance to speak...

BLOG.title: It’s official – Whiteley Shopping Centre is Excellent
BLOG.description: Whiteley is one of only two major new retail developments opening in the UK in 2013. Together with our project team, we have put sustainability at the heart of every stage of the development. During development, 99.5% of construction and demolition waste has been diverted from landfill through re-use on site or recovery off site. This has saved an estimated 112,000 tonnes of brick, tarmac, concrete, clay and other materials from landfill since July 2011 (as much as the weight of 7,700 London buses). It has also reduced lorry journeys, minimising our impact on local air quality and road networks....

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: Rock Up, Fussy Nation and Glow & Co Set to Climb into Whiteley

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Whiteley, Fareham is a 320,000 sq ft retail and leisure development in Hampshire which opened in May 2013.

The centre has 59 shops and restaurants and is anchored by a 60,000 sq ft M&S. Whiteley, Fareham is let to a great range of some of the best retailers in the UK including anchor tenants Marks & Spencer, Next and Tesco, as well as Topshop, H&M, River Island, Fat Face, Monsoon, Joules, Phase Eight, Tiger, Ernest Jones, Beaverbrooks and Boots. Recent retailers to join the scheme include Pandora, Smiggle and Specsavers.

Local independent retailers include Little Soles children's shoe shop, the Fabulous Bakers, Hair OTT, Imagin gift shop, Sweets & Treats sweet shop, Solent Cycles and Walker & Waterer estate agents.

24 of Whiteley, Fareham retailers feature an in store 'click and collect' service, while Boots offers a late night pharmacy. The centre's restaurants stay open until late, establishing the scheme as a night time destination.

The centre is home to ‘Rock Up’, the first indoor climbing and soft play centre of its kind within a shopping centre.

Restaurants and cafes include Caffe Nero, Chimichanga, Costa Coffee, Dean’s Diner, Frankie & Benny’s, Harvester, Prezzo, Starbucks, Subway, Wagamama, YO! Sushi and independent bistro Montagu's which has a glazed kiosk in the mall.

The centre also provides 1,355 car parking spaces with electric charging facilities for 6 vehicles.

Whiteley, Fareham’s exceptional design features contemporary shop units with dramatic double and triple height glazing and uses natural materials including high quality European oak panels. The design incorporates extensive energy efficient and sustainability features and has a BREEAM Excellent rating. The high quality public spaces and landscaped areas feature 15 specially commissioned bronze sculptures of woodland creatures.

Situated between the two harbour cities of Portsmouth and Southampton and adjacent to an existing Tesco supermarket, the scheme benefits from excellent accessibility via junction nine of the M27.

Whiteley, Fareham benefits from a large and affluent catchment of 1.2 million people with an estimated £3.1 billion of potential spend. The catchment is set to expand further in the foreseeable future with 3,500 new homes at North Whiteley.

An £18 million leisure extension opened in November 2015 at Whiteley, Fareham comprising a nine-screen Cineworld multiplex as well as seven new restaurants including Five Guys, Pizza Express, Nando’s, Dim-T, Coast to Coast and Wildwood Kitchen and Deli.

The scheme was developed in a 50:50 joint venture between British Land and Universities Superannuation Scheme.

Sustainability at Whiteley

  • More than 20 team members WorldHost customer service and Dementia Friendly trained.
  • Strong community programme, including fundraising events and our award-winning art: space initiative for young carers with arts charity Create.
  • 1st UK shopping centre to achieve the BREEAM Excellent sustainability rating.
  • 36,000 sq ft of photovoltaic panels – producing enough clean energy to power 60 homes for a year.
  • 277 mature trees planted along walkways and 100% sustainable timber used in construction.
  • Over 200 cycle spaces, as well as employee showers and free electric car charging points.
  • 99.5% of waste diverted from landfill during construction and 940 tonnes recycled last year.
  • 15 specially commissioned bronze sculptures of woodland creatures, alongside a new town square, pleasant walkways and independent local retailers.
  • 11 unemployed young people took part in our first retail training course at Whiteley last year, with around two-thirds moving into work and other positive outcomes soon afterwards.

BLOG.title: Broadgate Connect – Changing Lives
BLOG.description: Many of the people I’ve engaged with through Broadgate Connect would never otherwise have thought of trying to secure a job in the City. From long-term jobseekers to young people looking for their first job, it is so fulfilling to have a positive impact on an individual’s progression and success. I am grateful to Broadgate employers for the opportunities that they have created, opening doors for local people and giving them access to roles that many would never have imagined for themselves. In turn, it is great to see the employers benefiting from motivated, committed employees with new skills and ideas. Since...

BLOG.title: Broadgate Connect Benefits East London
BLOG.description:
Since we launched our innovative employment and skills initiative with community partner the East London Business Alliance (ELBA) in 2012, our project managers have engaged with 429 East London residents, helping connect them to job opportunities and work placements in the City. We are delighted at the success of the project, which is benefiting both local jobseekers and our Broadgate suppliers. Two thirds of the engaged candidates come from our target boroughs of Hackney and Tower Hamlets. More than 70% are from black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) groups. Benefits for local residents include:
Early access to job opportunities, with...

BLOG.title: Spring into Wellbeing at Broadgate
BLOG.description:
Research shows that a healthier workforce is generally more productive and happier, delivering benefits for both employees and employers. Over 35 teams kick-started their new year by battling it out on the ice with friends and colleagues in our popular Broomball tournaments. Others learnt how to skate with grace and style, thanks to lessons from our skate coach, Robert Burgerman, recently a coach on ITV’s Dancing on Ice.
Broomball players batting the ball with their ‘broom’ and young skaters building confidence and skills on the ice. Each year, we give local schoolchildren the chance to enjoy sessions for free. Summer Live will begin...

BLOG.title: Out with the Old and in with the New – Energy Efficient Lighting at Broadgate
BLOG.description:
We chose LED products because they offered energy savings, improved quality of light, longer rated lifetimes and a major reduction in maintenance costs compared with previous fittings. Here’s some of what we’ve replaced and installed across the Estate over the last two years:
80 fittings along the Great Eastern Walkway, from 150W to 36W LEDs – 76% more efficient 72 fittings in the EBRD staircase lobby towards Exchange Square, from 36W to 14W LEDs – 61% more efficient Fittings across the Bishopsgate service roadway from 150W to 14W LEDs – 91% more efficient Lamps in the Bishopsgate...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
1 Finsbury Avenue, one of the earliest buildings on the campus, will be refurbished in the coming years

Designed by Peter Foggo of Arup Associates, 1 Finsbury Avenue is a Grade II listed building, to the West of the campus, with good access to both Liverpool Street station and Moorgate. The eight storey building was completed in 1984, and in October 2015 we received a resolution to grant planning consent for a 300,000 sq ft refurbishment. The plans include a faithful restoration of the building’s façade as well as an extension, providing two further floors, and retail space on the ground floor.

These plans form part of our broader vision for Broadgate, to create a vibrant mixed use environment, building on its location around Liverpool Street station, a Crossrail station from 2018.

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
York House is located in the Portman Village just north of Oxford Street, and has been partially refurbished for British Land

York House is located on Seymour Street, within the Portman Village just north of Oxford Street. It is conveniently located for Marble Arch, Bond Street and Baker Street underground stations, with Marylebone and Paddington mainline stations nearby. The building was completed in early 2007 and provides over 90,000 sq ft of office space, 9,000 sq ft of retail space and 22 residential units.

British Land occupies around 40,000 sq ft of the office space as its head office and this area was recently refurbished, adding break out areas, as well as formal and informal meeting spaces to create a more modern, collaborative workspace.

York House is also situated adjacent to our Marble Arch House building.

Read more about Marble Arch House

Centrally located, covered shopping centre, including a Virgin Active health club and office space

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
An attractive and convenient shopping destination in West London, Ealing Broadway covers around 7.5 acres

Acquired in 2013, Ealing Broadway is a mixed use asset, covering around 340,000 sq ft of retail and leisure space and over 100,000 sq ft of office space. It comprises over 60 retail units, including anchor tenants Primark, Marks & Spencer and Tesco, as well as high street fashion labels H&M, New Look, Next and River Island, and a Virgin Active gym. The office space is let to Danone and HMRC.

Two adjoining assets have been acquired since acquisition, and we are part way through a comprehensive refurbishment. The food and leisure area was completed at the end of 2014, following which we added Turtle Bay, a Caribbean restaurant and bar and Limeyard, a French café, bar and restaurant concept. Existing dining options include Wagamama and Patisserie Valerie. The remaining works will be completed by the end of the year.

The shopping centre is very well located, in the centre of Ealing, with access to the underground and mainline rail station. Ealing is also on the Crossrail map, greatly improving journey times to the City, West End and Heathrow from 2018. Building on its excellent location, we have submitted plans for a 34,000 sq ft residential development and expect to be on site in 2016.

Sustainability at Ealing Broadway

  • Almost 40 team members WorldHost customer service and Dementia Friendly trained.
  • Long-standing community programme, including fundraising events and strong relationships with local partners such as Ealing Mencap.
  • 690 children have taken part in fun, educational literacy events at Ealing Broadway since 2013, through our partnership with the National Literacy Trust.
  • 28% less energy use since 2014, saving occupiers £74,100 and cutting carbon by more than 200 tonnes.
  • 1,200 tonnes of waste recycled over four years.

BLOG.title: Old Market Shopping Centre, Hereford turns one
BLOG.description: It’s been a fantastic year for the £90 million open-air shopping centre on the site of Hereford’s former livestock market. The 310,000 sq ft scheme was the largest retail development to open last year and opened 96% exchanged and under offer and is let to some of the best retailers in the UK. Old Market is a great example of a Place People Prefer. It’s a locally preferred place that captures a broad range of journeys. It’s the first major retail development in the city for 25 years and has helped Hereford climb 38 places in the retail rankings to reach...

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: Old Market, Hereford Now Fully Let

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Open air shopping centre in the middle of Hereford City centre, completed in 2014

Designed by architects Allies & Morrison, and Leslie Jones, Old Market Hereford was developed on the site of the old cattle market in Hereford City Centre. The scheme covers 305,000 sq ft and is virtually fully let, including anchor tenants Debenhams, who have taken an 85,000 sq ft store. The strong occupier line-up includes high street names such as H&M, Next, Fat Face, TK Maxx, Outfit and L’Occitane as well as Waitrose.

Leisure accounts for over 20% of the scheme by area, including a six-screen Odeon cinema, as well as restaurant operators Chimichanga, Wagamama, Wildwood Kitchen, Nando’s, Prezzo and Patisserie Valerie.

Old Market was the first major retail development in Hereford for 25 years. It brought over 1,000 jobs to the area, and increased Hereford’s shopper population by over 155,000 people, boosting the local economy by some £100 million.

BLOG.title: Solar Panels for a Low Carbon Future at St Stephen’s
BLOG.description: More than 1,100 panels, covering 55,000 sq ft of roof space, were installed over a four-week period at the end of 2015. This was the culmination of several years of research and hard work. With technology changing so fast, it was a balancing act to make sure that we invested in the right product, at the right time and for the right price. It has been a huge project and getting the panels installed was a major achievement. We’re now seeing the benefits – economically and environmentally. Not only are the panels set to generate a return on investment of 14%...

BLOG.title: Dementia Friendly Places
BLOG.description: We want our shopping destinations to be open to everyone to enjoy. Wide, safe walkways, convenient parking, accessible toilets and clear signage – this all helps. But, as a placemaker, we know that it’s our people on the ground who can make the biggest difference. So, alongside WorldHost customer service training, we’re making sure that our centre teams have the understanding and skills to help visitors who might need additional support. There are around 850,000 people with dementia in the UK, often cared for by family members. It can make an enormous difference to their day to encounter people who know...

BLOG.title: Shining Retail Stars of Tomorrow
BLOG.description: We’ve been supporting The Prince’s Trust’s Get into Retail course since 2007, helping young people gain the skills and experience needed to get a job in the retail sector. We’re delighted around two thirds of participants manage to move on to positive outcomes soon afterwards, such as work, education or further training, with others offered ongoing mentoring and support. In recent months, we’ve invested more than £140,000 in retail and hospitality training programmes at our properties around the UK, working with...

BLOG.title: Encouraging a Love of Reading at British Land Properties
BLOG.description:
Together, the National Literacy Trust and British Land are delivering a five-year programme, which nurtures a love for reading amongst thousands of children, often from disadvantaged communities. Why a love for reading matters* Research shows that there is a positive relationship between reading for enjoyment and a child’s achievement. Yet one child in five in the UK leaves primary school without achieving expected literacy levels. This can have a life long impact on their health, confidence, employability and happiness.
Our five-year programme British Land’s...

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
St Stephen's is a mixed-use scheme located at the heart of Hull city centre next to a fully integrated transport interchange. The scheme has transformed Hull's retail and leisure provision; the centre is now one of the top 20 in the UK.

The shopping centre is home to over 50 stores and restaurants including Next, Zara, Superdry, TK Maxx, H&M, Boux Avenue, Lipsy, Topshop/Topman, New Look and River Island, and IS anchored by a Tesco Extra.

St Stephen’s leisure offer includes a 7-screen Reel cinema, a gym, theatre and a Holiday Inn Express, plus a number of restaurants, bars and cafes including Nando’s, Handmade Burger Co, Prezzo and Starbucks. Plans are currently being developed to further enhance the leisure and restaurant offer with the addition of new operators adjacent to the cinema on the upper level.

The centre is has ample parking of 800 spaces.

St Stephen's is wholly owned by British Land.

Sustainability at St Stephen’s

  • Over 50 team members WorldHost customer service and Dementia Friendly trained.
  • Award-winning community programme, with local partners including Hull Children’s University, Hull FC Community Foundation and Stepney Primary School.
  • 690 children have taken part in fun, educational literacy events at St Stephen’s since 2013, through our partnership with the National Literacy Trust.
  • 1/3 of all electricity in common areas comes from photovoltaic panels and we’ve reduced energy use by 40% since 2010, saving occupiers £383,100 and cutting carbon by 2,500 tonnes.
  • 1 million litres of rainwater harvested each year and 15 tonnes of food waste recycled through the food-to-water treatment plant on site.
  • Over 200 unemployed young people have benefited from retail training at St Stephen’s since 2007, through our award-winning Get into Retailing programme.

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Eden Walk is a 50:50 joint venture with Universities Superannuation Scheme, located in the centre of Kingston

British Land acquired a 50% share in Eden Walk in 2012. It is an open air scheme, covering nearly 280,000 sq ft, anchored by Marks & Spencer, Sainsbury’s and Boots with around 20 other retail units, three office buildings and a 700 space multi-storey car park. Catering options include Paul’s bakery and The Cheeky Pea, an independent café Mediterranean café specialising in hummus and falafel.

British Land has long term plans for a £250 million mixed use redevelopment of Eden Walk, to include public spaces, leisure, retail and residential.

A sad truth is that nearly two thirds of “out” graduates today go back “into the closet” for...

BLOG.title: Thousands Flock to the Cheesegrater for Open House London
BLOG.description: This event takes place for one weekend each year, giving people the chance to see amazing architecture in every neighbourhood of London, normally off limits to the public. The Leadenhall Building, nicknamed the Cheesegrater, welcomed over 7,500 people across the weekend. More than 1,000 people also gained behind-the-scenes access to buildings at Broadgate in the City and Regent’s Place in London’s West End. Our guests at The Leadenhall Building enjoyed an exhibition in the public space on the building’s rise to fame, discovered a two-metre tall Lego model of London’s latest landmark, took the panoramic lifts to the 40th floor and marvelled...

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: British Land and Oxford Properties complete the leasing of The Leadenhall Building
Clydesdale Bank selects The Leadenhall Building as its new London office
Leonid Shutov, restaurateur behind Bob Bob Ricard, to open first City restaurant at The Leadenhall Building
Hedge fund Quadrature Capital signs at The Leadenhall Building
The Duke of Cambridge and Prince Harry attend the opening of The Leadenhall Building
British Land and Oxford Properties let two more floors at The Leadenhall Building
Q1 2015/16 Trading Statement
DRW Trading Group agrees terms at The Leadenhall Building

Leading IT company IPsoft Agrees Terms at The Leadenhall Building
Update on The Leadenhall Building
The City’s newest meeting point unveiled at The Leadenhall Building

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
The Leadenhall Building is a joint venture between British Land and Oxford Properties.

Designed by Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners, The Leadenhall Building is a unique 603,000 sq ft office tower prominently located in the centre of the City of London. Its defining feature is its distinctive tapering shape, which when viewed from the West appears to ‘lean away’ from St Paul’s Cathedral. This was developed as a response to the specific planning requirements which protect the views of St Paul’s from a number of locations in London.

Its unique shape provides a mix of flexible office space, with floorplates of various sizes, ranging from 17,700 sq ft on the lower floors to 6,500 sq ft at the top of the tower, all with spectacular views over London. The core of the building has been located on the north side improving the efficiency of the space, and providing for more regular office areas, which better meet the needs of occupiers. The spectacular scale of the seven storey high landscaped galleria at ground level is unprecedented in London. In September 2015, the building was named ‘Building of the Year’ by the Worshipful Company of Architects and in October 2015 it was formally opened by the Duke of Cambridge and Prince Harry.

The building is a joint venture with Oxford Properties, the global investor, developer and manager of real estate. It incorporates some of the most advanced construction approaches and technologies available, with more than 80% of the components prefabricated off-site.

The building has let well, breaking records for city rents several times over, and has attracted a broad mix of occupiers for this area of the city, including Rothesay Life, IP Soft, Affinity Shipping as well as the building’s architects, Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners and our Joint Venture partners OMERS. It is now 98% let/under offer, with just one vacant floor remaining.

The Leadenhall Building was one of the first buildings in the UK to be awarded WiredScore's highest level of certification, Platinum, as endorsed by the Mayor of London which indicates a building with great digital connectivity and infrastructure.

Sustainability at Leadenhall

  • Triple-layer glass ‘skin’, with blinds that respond to the sun’s movement – keeping the office space comfortably cool and cutting energy use for artificial chillers.
  • 16,600 people benefited from our London community programme last year, including young people taking part in arts initiatives at The Leadenhall Building during Sculpture in the City.
  • Excellent BREEAM sustainability rating.
  • 293 energy meters installed for billing and measurement, so that occupiers can save money and cut carbon, with smart design set to save 14,961 tonnes of carbon over 60 years.
  • 95% of waste diverted from landfill during construction and 990 tonnes recycled last year.
  • 9,800 jobs supported during development and £376 million gross value added to the UK economy.
  • £2.8 million spent with local firms during construction and 18% of the site workforce were local residents, with jobs further afield including steelworkers in Bolton and carpenters in Scotland.

As a leading property company, we need to be able to predict the operational energy performance our new developments are likely to achieve and to have performance benchmarks, so that we can target our engineering teams to operate our buildings as efficiently as the design allows and feed learning back to our design teams. We therefore welcomed the 2013 release of the CIBSE TM54 methodology for evaluating the operational energy performance of buildings at the design stage. This provides the tools for more comprehensive predictions of likely operational energy consumption than earlier methodologies. How does TM54 differ from other modelling?

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: British Land Takes Drake Circus, Plymouth to the Next Stage with £40m Leisure Development

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Drake Circus, one of the West Country's most popular shopping destinations, is located in the centre of Plymouth and is the city's first covered shopping centre. The centre has a large catchment area of over half a million people – the second highest of any UK city – and an annual footfall of nearly 19 million people.

The 412,000 sq ft centre, which opened in 2006, is a modern, well configured and attractive environment for people to shop in. It has around 70 shops and restaurants and 1,270 car parking spaces. Key occupiers include M&S, Apple, Primark, Next, Topshop/Topman, H&M, New Look, River Island, Monsoon, Fat Face, Hotel Chocolat, schuh, Jones Bootmaker. The food and beverage offer includes Yo! Sushi, Ed’s Easy Diner, Starbucks and Costa.

Since British Land acquired Drake Circus in 2011, it has successfully attracted a range of new brands including Apple, Fat Face and Yo! Sushi. 10,000 sq ft of lettings were agreed recently adding new brands such as JD Sports, Tiger and Cath Kidston, and bringing occupancy to 100%.

In 2014, British Land signed an agreement with Plymouth City Council to develop Drake Circus Leisure, a 100,000 sq ft leisure scheme next to the shopping centre, which is due to open in Summer 2018. The £40 million development will include a 12-screen Cineworld cinema and 6 restaurant units, broadening the appeal of Drake Circus, establishing it as an evening destination and extending its trading hours.

Drake Circus is wholly owned by British Land.

Sustainability at Drake Circus

  • Over 60 team members WorldHost customer service and Dementia Friendly trained.
  • 1,200 schoolchildren took part in water-based educational sessions over three years, through our support for local children's sailing charity Horizons.
  • 1,030 children have taken part in fun, educational literacy events at Drake Circus since 2011, through our partnership with the National Literacy Trust.
  • 14% less energy use since 2012, saving occupiers £68,500 and cutting carbon by almost 200 tonnes.
  • 1,900 tonnes of waste recycled over five years.
  • More than 20 unemployed young people have benefited from retail training at Drake Circus over two years, with 14 moving into work and other positive outcomes soon afterwards.

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: British Land reveals details of Meadowhall’s £300m proposed Leisure Hall
PwC report reveals full extent of Meadowhall’s positive impact
British Land mixes it up with a burst of new lettings at Meadowhall
Meadowhall Celebrates 25 Years of Bringing People Together with £50m Refurbishment
Next Home & Garden Opens at Meadowhall

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Meadowhall, located on the outskirts of Sheffield, is Yorkshire’s premier shopping destination and one of only six out-of-town super regional shopping centres in the UK.

The shopping centre provides 1.4 million sq ft of high quality retail and leisure space to a diverse range of brands including Marks & Spencer, Debenhams, House of Fraser, Apple, Zara, White Company, Jigsaw, White Stuff, Hollister, Primark, Topshop, Reiss, Victoria’s Secret, and Vue Cinemas. The strength of Meadowhall’s appeal to retailers is reflected in its consistently high occupancy levels and long weighted average lease length.

Meadowhall has around 300 stores and a leisure offer which now boasts an 11-screen cinema, Oasis Dining Quarter, which includes brands such as Tapas Revolution, Wagamama, TGI Friday’s, Nando’s, Zizzi’s, Five Guys and, Carluccio’s. The centre also benefits from 12,000 free car parking spaces, as well as the centre’s own public transport interchange for local and regional bus, train and Supertram services that run throughout the day.

To mark the 25 year anniversary of Meadowhall, a substantial £60 million internal refurbishment started in late 2015 and will be completed by the end of 2017. The extensive works will create distinct districts within the centre, each with a different finish including wood and punctured metal. The refurbishment will also enable a number of retailers to install double height shop fronts.

The Park Lane area underwent a recent refresh, following which it has successfully attracted a number of premium retailers, including The White Company, Jigsaw and White Stuff. Meadowhall’s premium offer already includes LK Bennett, Reiss and Kurt Geiger.

We are also drawing up plans for a 330,000 sq ft Leisure Hall at Meadowhall. The plans represent the single biggest investment in Meadowhall since it opened more than 25 years ago. At over £300 million, the proposals are also one of the largest investments in the Sheffield City Region for a decade and will create over 1,000 jobs.

The proposed Leisure Hall will add a range of dining and entertainment experiences not currently available at the centre. These include a number of new restaurants, a state-of-the-art cinema to replace the existing cinema in the Oasis Dining Quarter, a new cafe court, gym, and other leisure space that could be used to offer everything from ten-pin bowling to indoor golf.

Meadowhall is owned in a 50:50 joint venture with Norges Bank Investment Management.

Sustainability at Meadowhall

  • All 260 team members WorldHost customer service and Dementia Friendly trained.
  • £1.8m community programme over five years through cash, time, gifts-in-kind and fundraising, for local partners such as St Luke’s Hospice and the Children’s Hospital Charity.
  • 810 children have taken part in fun, educational literacy events at Meadowhall since 2013, through our partnership with the National Literacy Trust.
  • 47% less energy use since 2009, saving occupiers £3.1m and cutting carbon by more than 19,000 tonnes.
  • 92 million litres of mains water saved through a pioneering borehole and rainwater harvesting over five years, with other innovations including an on-site recycling facility and electric car charging points.
  • 660 apprenticeships at Meadowhall over five years, supported by The Source Skills Academy, an award-winning training facility set up by British Land and Sheffield City Council in 2003.
  • Around half the materials and labour for our Meadowhall refurbishment are being sourced from companies within the Sheffield City Region, bringing £25m to the regional economy.

BLOG.title: Meadowhall at 25 – supporting employment across the Sheffield City Region
BLOG.description: Like many people from Sheffield, I grew up visiting both Meadowhall and the City Centre regularly for shopping and leisure trips, with each location offering something different. I remember going to Meadowhall in the first few weeks of its opening as a 10-year-old boy and being amazed by the size of the place and how much it offered. For me, Meadowhall has always been a great place to shop and spend time with friends or family; also as a place to work, with some of my schoolmates finding their first job at Meadowhall and many local people developing their careers in...

BLOG.title: Sustainability Innovations at Meadowhall
BLOG.description: I’ve been at Meadowhall since the beginning, in fact since before the beginning! The Centre opened in September 1990, but I’d already started working on the construction of Meadowhall in October 1989 on a three-month carpentry contract. I was a young lad, single, living at home, going nightclubbing and getting lifts to work. More than 25 years later, I’m still here – although now married, with my own home, two children and a car. It’s been a fantastic career for me, with Meadowhall funding my education early on and letting me work flexibly while I attended night school. I’ve progressed through...

BLOG.description: Access to the right space is often key to the success of entrepreneurs, start-ups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). This is about more than four walls. It’s about places where they can connect and share; flexible, affordable spaces on short leases, at affordable rents, with grow-on space. Places that project the right image for budding brands, and offer them much-needed amenities and collaborative opportunities. In the City and East London, there is a lack of supply for this kind of space, creating issues for the growing tech industry in the area. We’re looking at how we can do more to...

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: British Land submits planning application for Blossom Street site, E1

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
At Blossom Street, Shoreditch we are working in partnership with The City of London Corporation on a mixed use development

The development covers three sites over two acres, fronting onto Shoreditch High Street and Norton Folgate, immediately to the north of Spitalfields and the core City of London market. The site has potential for around 350,000 sq ft of office, retail and residential accommodation, in a mix of new, retained and refurbished buildings. The proposed scheme will comprise a mix of floorplates, providing character offices suitable for the tech and creative industries, with a focus on small and medium sized businesses. Architects AHMM (Allford Hall Monaghan Morris) are the lead architects working alongside DSDHA, Duggan Morris and Stanton Williams in developing our proposals. In recent years, this area has emerged as a hub for the tech and creative sectors, and is well located for Liverpool Street station, including Crossrail from 2018.

British Land acquired the site through an option agreement with The City of London Corporation who will be closely involved in throughout the development. On practical completion, British Land will acquire a long leasehold interest in the site.

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Teesside is located between Stockton and Middlesbrough town centres. With 48 units covering nearly 480,000 sq ft, it attracts over 11 million shoppers every year and is home to some of the best known retailers in the UK.

Teesside is ranked by CACI as the number one super park in the UK.

Key occupiers include M&S, Next, Boots, WH Smith, New Look, River Island, H&M, Outfit and TK Maxx. Teesside was the first shopping park store for Schuh, and Simply Be/Jacamo.

Sustainability at Teesside

  • All 18 team members WorldHost customer service and Dementia Friendly trained.
  • Long-standing community programme, including fundraising events and strong relationships with local partners such as Zoe’s Place Children’s Hospice.
  • 1,290 children have taken part in fun, educational literacy events at Teesside since 2011, through our partnership with the National Literacy Trust.
  • 31% less energy use since 2009, saving occupiers £135,000 and cutting carbon by 860 tonnes.
  • Zero waste to landfill, with 250 tonnes recycled over the last five years.
  • More than 20 unemployed young people have benefited from retail training at Teesside over two years, with 70% moving into work and other positive outcomes soon afterwards.

BLOG.title: Seeing is Believing
BLOG.description: Yalding House is our new office development in the West End. The building has a rich heritage: it was built as a motorbike workshop in the 1930s, but from the 1950s was a BBC Radio studio, home to Radio One through the eighties, nineties and early noughties. We acquired the building in 2001 and when the BBC opted to move on we took the opportunity to extend and refurbish it as an office building. We were keen however to keep the original look and feel as a reminder of the building’s former life which we think will appeal to a broad...

NEWSRELEASE.NEWS_TITLE: British Land launches Yalding House, W1

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
The 29,000 sq ft building provides 23,000 sq ft of contemporary office space across five floors, with the newly added upper floor boasting a terrace and additional 2,100 sq ft mezzanine level, in addition to 6,000 sq ft of retail space. The refurbishment, led by BuckleyGrayYeoman, has retained much of the original character of the building, with the brickwork and steel structure exposed on the office floors, thereby maximising floor to ceiling height.

Sustainability at Yalding House

  • 100% sustainable timber used in construction and 99% of construction waste recycled.
  • 59% lower annual carbon emissions through smart design.
  • 56 cycle spaces and lockers added, along with showers and changing facilities.
  • Bird and bat boxes and an insect hotel to encourage biodiversity.

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Glasgow Fort is a 700,000 sq ft (510,000 sq ft ex mezzanine) retail park built in 2004 which comprises 91 retail brands. It is one of the pre-eminent fashion-led parks in the UK. It provides the vibrancy of a high street environment with the convenience of an out-of-town location.

The flexibility of Glasgow Fort’s design allows for a greater range of unit sizes which, when combined with the scheme's location, provides a superior shopping centre environment. Glasgow Fort is ranked by CACI as the number one retail park in Scotland.

Key occupiers at Glasgow Fort include Next, Boots, Zara, New Look, River Island, TK Maxx, Mamas & Papas, H&M and Office. This is the first shopping park store for several brands, including Zara, Office, Swarovski and Chisholm Hunter.

Glasgow Fort recently underwent a £33 million pound retail extension which included an 80,000 sq ft (including mezzanine space) M&S as well a Fat Face store and a Wagamama restaurant. A leisure extension was completed in 2013, comprising an eight-screen Vue multiplex cinema and 24,000 sq ft of restaurant space.

Glasgow Fort includes parking spaces for 1,900 cars. Construction has begun on a new multi-storey car park providing 600 additional parking spaces with 4 ground-floor catering units, due to open in 2016.

Glasgow Fort is owned by the Hercules Unit Trust in which, as of March 2016, British Land has a 75% share.

BLOG.title: Police Partnerships for Safer Communities and Better Business

Retailers came fully on board and have been working with the Centre team and local police ever since, proactively sharing information and applying the latest crime prevention techniques....

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Paddington Central is an 11-acre mixed use campus close to Paddington station in London’s West End.

Located on the edge of the West End, approximately 15 minutes’ walk from Marble Arch, our Paddington Central campus is well served by Paddington station, a major London rail and tube interchange, with excellent connections to Heathrow via the Heathrow Express. From 2018, Paddington will be one of only three Crossrail stations in the West End, with improved connections to Heathrow, the City and Canary Wharf.

The campus comprises seven separate modern buildings, and a retail & leisure cluster, in total covering 1.2 million sq ft. British Land bought a majority ownership in the campus in July 2013, comprising 610,000 sq ft of income generating properties. In April 2015, we acquired One Sheldon Square, strategically located at the entrance to the campus, and increasing our ownership to 800,000 sq ft of income generating properties. In addition, British Land owns the freehold in respect of 200 residential units which sit above the retail area and has management responsibility for the whole campus.

British Land also owns 436,000 sq ft of the development space including 146,000 sq ft currently under construction at 4 Kingdom Street, and 210,000 sq ft of consented space at 5 Kingdom Street. In 2018, we will take ownership the Crossrail box which offers 80,000 sq ft of development potential and sits below our development at 4 Kingdom Street which is currently under construction and will complete in 2017.

Key occupiers

Microsoft, Visa, Accor, Kingfisher, Statoil, Vertex Pharmaceuticals, Cerner and Prudential.

Sustainability at Paddington Central

  • New green walls added to the campus, along with mature trees, extra seating, wider walkways, upgraded cycle routes and other public realm improvements.
  • 16,600 people benefited from our London community programme last year, with partners at Paddington Central including the Canal & River Trust, North Paddington Food Bank and Westminster Academy.
  • World’s First BREEAM Outstanding Fit Out achieved at 2 Kingdom Street by Broadgate Estates.
  • 21% less energy use last year, cutting occupiers’ energy bills and reducing carbon by 1,100 tonnes.
  • More than 1,000 tonnes of waste recycled over three years.

Through our first phase of improvements, we enhanced the canalside area and other public spaces, embedding our wellbeing principles throughout. We also added different types of landscaping, creating green walls, planting mature trees and filling large planters with herbs. Good news for people and nature, with growing evidence that green...

The route tracks Paddington’s favourite locations, taking in museums, parks, shops and landmarks. Together with our Paddington Central team, we wanted our bear to be a beacon of excellence within our community and so we invited students from nearby Westminster Academy to present their designs for his appearance. CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Regent's Place is a 13-acre, fully managed campus in London's West End home to over 16,000 workers and residents.

Fronting onto the Euston Road, the campus benefits from its location between Great Portland Street and Warren Street underground stations, with access to the Circle, Metropolitan, Hammersmith and City, Northern and Victoria lines.

We have completely transformed Regent's Place in recent years. Key milestones included the purchase of the western end of the campus from The Crown Estate in 2005 and the subsequent development of 10 and 20 Triton Street which were completed in 2009. We have also recently completed the refurbishment 338 Euston Road.

10 – 30 Brock Street, the most recent development was completed in 2013. 10 Brock Street, the largest building was designed by Wilkinson Eyre and provides 340,000 sq ft of office accommodation. All floors have been let to a diverse range of occupiers including Debenhams, Santander, Manchester City FC and Facebook.

At the heart of the campus is Regent’s Place Plaza, a place to meet, relax and be entertained. It plays host to an array of regular events, from food markets to salsa dancing as well as our summer of sport, including Wimbledon, the Ashes and the Rugby World Cup.

Throughout Regent’s Place the open spaces and buildings are enhanced by numerous public art installations, from both internationally recognised names as well as young breakthrough artists commissioned by British Land, and the Diorama Theatre showcases some of the best theatre companies from across the UK.

The campus also includes two residential towers, One Osnaburgh Street and the Triton Building. The apartments have all been sold but British Land retains the freehold.

To commemorate 30 years working at Regent’s Place we launched a report, based on independent research, assessing our social, economic and environmental impact: Regent’s Place at 30

Key occupiers

Aegis Group, ATOS, Facebook, Gazprom, HM Government, Lend Lease, Debenhams

Sustainability at Regent’s Place

  • 739,000 sq ft of BREEAM Excellent offices and 52,150 sq ft of green space created since 2009.
  • £50m local investment at Regent’s Place since 2007, through our community programme and planning agreements, funding an employment and training centre, new theatre, affordable housing and more.
  • Over 8,400 people benefited from our Regent’s Place community programme last year, including our award-winning partnership with New Diorama Theatre.
  • 52% reduction in energy intensity since 2009, saving occupiers £1.8m and cutting carbon by 10,500 tonnes.
  • 580,000 litres of rainwater harvested last year and 2,800 tonnes of waste recycled over five years.
