CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Broadgate is a 30-acre campus in the heart of London's Square Mile, owned in a 50:50 joint venture with GIC.

Since opening, the estate has been progressively developed and now includes 16 separate buildings, with their own unique character, covering 4.7 million sq ft. The office buildings are set around four landscaped squares each providing an attractive working environment enhanced by restaurants, pubs, shops and health clubs.

The campus was constructed in phases, with the earliest buildings, including 1, 2 & 3 Finsbury Avenue, 1-3 Broadgate and 100 Liverpool Street completed in the 1980s; and 10 Exchange Square (2004), The Broadgate Tower and 201 Bishopsgate (both 2008) completed later. Nearly 20% of the campus has been refurbished in the last few years, including 199 Bishopsgate and 5 Broadgate, which was custom built for UBS. Broadgate Circle has also been comprehensively redeveloped to create a high end food and beverage destination for this part of the City.

Due to its excellent location - it has been built around Liverpool Street station - Broadgate has become a dynamic and thriving business community. With over 30,000 workers it is home to some of the world's biggest corporations and top professional practices. An estimated 250,000 people pass through Broadgate every day, and this is expected to increase with the opening of Crossrail in 2018. It is also well located to benefit from growth and regeneration to the north and east of the city. Our vision for this campus is to create a vibrant, mixed use environment, meeting the changing nature of demands in this dynamic area of the City.

Looking forward, our development plans for the campus include the redevelopment of 100 Liverpool Street, where we have already received planning permission; 1 Finsbury Avenue, where we have received consent for a 303,000 sq ft development; and 2 – 3 Finsbury Avenue where we are developing our plans.

Key occupiers

UBS, RBS, Herbert Smith, Mayer Brown, Credit Agricole, Reed Smith, ICAP, Deutsche Bank, Ashurst, Henderson, Société Générale

Sustainability at Broadgate

  • 1.7 million sq ft of BREEAM Excellent offices and 17,500 sq ft of green space created since 2009.
  • Over 800 people benefited from our Broadgate community programme last year, which includes award-winning arts initiatives for schoolchildren.
  • 37% reduction in energy intensity since 2009, saving occupiers £5.7m and cutting carbon by 34,300 tonnes.
  • 2.8 million litres of rainwater harvested last year and 9,300 tonnes of waste recycled over five years.
  • 174 East London jobseekers have found work through our Broadgate Connect employment and training initiative since 2012.

PROP_TAB.title: This estate also includes 175 Bishopsgate which was sold and is not owned by the joint venture.

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Ropemaker Place is one of the City of London's most attractive yet sustainable buildings. It provides around 593,000 sq ft of which 565,000 sq ft is offices and the remainder retail.

The 20-storey building, designed by Arup Associates for both professional and financial services occupiers, has two trading floors at the lower levels, with a variety of floor plates above.

The building which was completed in early May 2009, is now fully let to a range of banks and financial services companies.

Key occupiers

Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ Ltd, Mitsubishi UFJ Securities, International Plc, Liberum Capital, Markit, Macquarie Group

Sustainability

Ropemaker Place was the first building in the City of London to achieve LEED Platinum pre-certification for sustainability. It also has a BREEAM Excellent sustainability rating and is designed to be 33% more energy efficient than current standards and to use 50% less mains water than the norm.

All energy for heating water and space can come from renewable resources, the biomass boiler and solar panels, and the building incorporates our new energy metering system and optimisation process. It also has 30,000 sq ft of green roof space and a rainwater harvesting system.

Our joint venture with Sainsbury's includes 40 standalone food stores, with a total of 2.9 million sq ft (the average store size is 72,500 sq ft).

Located throughout the UK but with an emphasis toward the South East, the stores have an average unexpired term of 16.5 years and are regularly refurbished and extended by Sainsbury's. During the last 12 months, Sainsbury’s have refurbished five of our stores and undertaken three extensions.

Sustainability

With Sainsbury's we are carrying out Energy Performance Certificate ratings at all our superstores and have commissioned a review of flood risks.

Nine of our stores were refurbished by Tesco during the year with a further 17 stores scheduled for refurbishment over the next 12 months reflecting the renewed focus on improving existing stores. During the year we have also funded two store extensions.

Sustainability

CONTENT_TAB.ABOUT:
Covering 46-acres, our site at Canada Water currently comprises Surrey Quays Shopping Centre, Surrey Quays Leisure Park, and the SE16 Printworks. The site was assembled over five years for a total investment of £250 million, creating one of the largest mixed use regeneration projects in London.

Canada Water is a designated London Opportunity Area, and is well located in Zone 2, with direct transport links to Canary Wharf, the City, and West End and to the tech hubs around Shoreditch. The area will also benefit from the opening of Crossrail at Canary Wharf in 2019.

This is a major project with the potential for around 7m sq ft (gross area) of mixed use space (5.5m sq ft on a net basis), and will be delivered in a number of phases. Our plan is to deliver an exciting new place for London which connects with the local community and is integrated with the surrounding area; green spaces form the backbone of the scheme, with smartly designed buildings, in a network of living streets and waterways which draw on the heritage of the area. Benefiting from our Placemaking experience across our portfolio, our proposals aim to create a vibrant environment which includes restaurants, leisure and entertainment opportunities alongside community and cultural facilities. Our initial plans envisage a true mix of uses with new homes (including private rented), as well as workspace, retail and academic accommodation. We are working with the London Borough of Southwark as freeholders of part of the site and the local community to develop our proposals, and more than 2,000 visitors have attended our Canada Water consultation events since spring 2014.
